PM11:09am

Almost three years ago, on 8 July 2015, one of the authors of this report, then working in index structuring, launched a China A index based on an advised systematic and value strategy. Commercially speaking, there could not have been worse timing. On that day, the CSI 300 lost 7.8%, a very severe fall even in the context of high volatility created by a fast-deflating China equity bubble.

Otter @A.M mainly I rested
Excel Developer @VV75: 8.6, which is Pi (3.141) * 1000 / 365.25
PM11:09am

Fast forward to today and the market landscape has dramatically changed. Growth has stabilised, CNY policy has improved and corporate earnings have recovered. Of course, new risks are emerging: some are ‘Made in America' (dollar appreciation and trade tensions), others are domestic (the war on leverage). But perhaps the biggest risk, as often in markets, is that of complacency. A China hard landing has disappeared from investors' radars. This lack of concern is also identified by our proprietary China Hard Landing newsflow which points to an unusually low probability of recession. On the whole, the balance of risk is shifting towards a more constructive stance.

The equity market has opened: Stock Connect has become the favoured market access channel for investors on both sides of the border and MSCI is about to include A shares in its range of international indices. The inclusion of mainland China equities will probably add little flow this year but we believe it will modify perceptions. There is a growing sense that the whole China market has become investable for foreign investors. In other words, the investment pool has expanded.

Pharma @Otter, apologies, although the good wishes remain. Strange the notions one gets. I have mental pictures of many of the people on this site, and they are probably all wrong.

11:10 am
PM11:10am

We divide this report into three parts:

In the first part, we summarise the investment case ranging from the diversification benefits of holding China equities in a global portfolio to valuation and monetary policy at a time of financial deleveraging.

Then we explore investment opportunities in both onshore and offshore shares. The nature of institutions- a command economy where the Party leads- gives the political cycle a prominent role in shaping investment opportunities. Major policies, including deleveraging, Manufacturing in China 2025 (MiC 2025), rebalancing to consumption or the one-belt-one-road, influence the share prices of listed companies. But it is not only the policy direction that matters, it is also the way the policy is executed and potential disruptions (a trade war?)? Based on this framework, we propose four key calls articulated around deleveraging, MiC 2025, consumption and trade war.

Finally, we review the China equity market structure. We cover more specifically three subjects: the size of the market, how to access it (for the most part courtesy of our Equity Quant Research team), and how different the China equity market is- which brings us to the role of SOEs, the existence of an onshore/offshore premium and the returns dispersion between the different equity indices.

BE11:16am

Ryanair delivered record FY2018 profits at the top end of
guidance – net profit of €1.45bn (Davy: €1.423bn, consensus
€1.441bn) and EPS growth of 15%. The focus, inevitably, will be
on guidance – net profit of €1.25-1.35bn (consensus: €1.374bn).
The revenue guidance and implied ancillary growth look robust,
although there are additional costs (+6% ex-fuel and +9%
including fuel). However, we view this as investing now for a 200-
plus customer business and assume “flat or slightly declining non-fuel unit costs” to resume thereafter. We believe Ryanair’s
industry-leading competitive advantage remains and thus see no
reason to change our 12-month ‘Outperform’ rating or €18 price
target. We maintain our forecasts for FY2019 at €1.31bn but
modestly lower our FY2020 forecasts by 5% to €1.35bn (marking to market for fuel).

It is clear that Ryanair remains the marker leader with a very strong competitive position. Its balance sheet is pristine – BBB+ rated, 400 owned aircraft (at significant discounts to current market value) with over €2bn in free cash from operations per annum and only €283m in net debt. This is despite capex of €1.5bn in FY2018 and returning over €6bn to shareholders since 2008.

The investment over the next six years in 210 Boeing Max Gamechanger aircraft (deliveries start in April 2019), ten-year CFM engine maintenance deal, hangers, training programmes and simulators shows the steps that Ryanair has taken to invest for growth. With only 15% of the pan-European market, it is clearly going to be a leader in consolidation – primarily organically.

BE11:21am

Ryanair remains, and will continue to be, one of the largest, most efficient, European consumer growth plays. Despite the share volatility, we do not see the 14x multiple as expensive. We retain our ‘Outperform’ rating.

BE11:22am

We see the risk of further increases of Ryanair’s personnel cost over the next quarters and disagreements with labour unions. We believe Ryanair’s current airport costs are not sustainable in the medium to long term. While we expect a positive yield development for easyJet, we expect only flat yield development for Ryanair during the summer flight schedule. In our view, for many investors, Ryanair’s equity story since 2014 has been based on a strong support for yields from the airline’s entry into primary airports,
where average yields are higher than in the group’s network. Despite strong capacity growth in 2014-17 in primary airports, which should have reached maturity by now, Ryanair’s yields have not seen a significant support so far. We consider that Ryanair’s business risk profile has deteriorated in recent quarters and therefore, we value Ryanair at a 20% discount to its average ten-year P/E 2019E multiple of 14.4x (i.e. with a multiple of 11.5x) which results in a fair value of EUR13.7 per share.

While the focus of the Tesco-Booker merger has been on cost synergies, we think the L/T growth potential of the combination is underappreciated on two counts. (1) The addressable Wholesale market is much larger (c.£90bn) than oft quoted (£30bn) vs, Booker (£5.6bn). (2) Tesco’s new synergy sales target of £2.5bn embeds M/T LFL volume growth of +1%/+2% in its core categories. Beyond the £2.5bn, we believe a Club format would leverage both offers and resonate with Tesco’s brand DNA.

wayneJ Second Forester's question - do they really mean HMRC or Companies House?
BE11:41am

We believe Booker reinforces Tesco’s ability to drive sustainable FCF and a progressive dividend. Discounting back, we target an undemanding 5.5% 2019/20E FCF Yield (vs. 5% for the sector).

BE12:00pm

We believe the shares are fundamentally fairly valued, considering the lack of visibility on future cash flows & higher execution risk. We estimate Ocado will not become FCF positive until FY2022e. Given the capital intensive nature of international deals and lack of transparency of deal terms, we find it difficult to have conviction on the deals' long-term cash flow profile and thus value accretion.While Ocado's solid operational track record gives us confidence in management's ability to execute, the large number of projects occurring simultaneously does present a greater degree of execution risk than previously.
